titleStmt.title: Continuous Sliding-Modes Control Strategies for Quad-Rotor Robust Tracking: Real-Time Application

analytic.title: Continuous Sliding-Modes Control Strategies for Quad-Rotor Robust Tracking: Real-Time Application

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The design of robust tracking control for Quad-Rotors is an important and challenging problem nowadays. In this paper a robust tracking output-control strategy is proposed for a Quad-Rotor under the influence of external disturbances and uncertainties. Such a strategy is composed of a Finite-Time Sliding-Mode Observer (FT-SMO) which estimates the full state from the measurable output and identifies some type of disturbances; and also of a combination between PID controllers and Continuous Sliding-Modes Controllers (Continuous-SMCs), that robustly track a desired time-varying trajectory with exponential convergence and despite the influence of external disturbances and uncertainties. The closed-loop stability is provided based on Input-to-State Stability (ISS) and Finite-Time ISS (FT-ISS) properties. Finally, experimental results in real-time show the performance of the proposed control strategy.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: T HE Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) research has attracted a lot of attention during the last decade. This interest is mainly given by the low cost of this type of vehicles and its large application range in diverse areas as: security, surveillance, video and film production, delivery, health, maintenance, transportation, etc. Between all these UAVs, the Quad-Rotors are considered as the most used vehicles due to its useful flight modes, its simplicity of operation and variety of sizes.

Despite the fact that the literature related to control design of Quad-Rotors is extensive, in this introduction the robust tracking control problem is the main focus. In this vein, in [1] a closed-form control scheme is proposed to track a desired trajectory in a Quad-Rotor under uncertainties providing stabilization and tracking in a practical sense. A switching model predictive controller is designed in [2] for achieving a precise trajectory under the presence of forcible wind gusts. The
The authors thank the financial support from CONACYT 270504, 785635, 817174, project 134534 and from TECNM projects.

H. Ríos is with CONACYT-TECNM/Instituto Tecnol ógico de La Laguna, Divisi ón de Estudios de Posgrado e Investigaci ón, Blvd. Revoluci ón y Cuauht émoc S/N, C.P. 27000, Torre ón, Coahuila, M éxico (phone: +52 871-7051331 EXT 109; fax: +52 871-7051331; e-mail: hriosb@correo.itlalaguna.edu.mx). R. Falc ón, O. A. Gonz ález and A. Dzul are with TECNM/Instituto Tecnol ógico de La Laguna, Divisi ón de Estudios de Posgrado e Investigaci ón, Blvd. Revoluci ón y Cuauht émoc S/N, C.P. 27000, Torre ón, Coahuila, M éxico.

performance of this strategy is validated through experimental studies including aggressive attitude regulation maneuvers and forcible wind-gust attenuation. In [3] a disturbance Sliding-Mode Observer (SMO) approach is proposed to design a robust flight controller for a Quad-Rotor in the presence of unknown disturbances. In the same context of Sliding-Mode Control (SMC) theory, in [4] a Super-Twisting algorithm (STA) is presented for the attitude tracking control problem of a Quad-Rotor ensuring robustness with respect to external disturbances but acting only on the attitude dynamics. A direct and indirect model reference adaptive control, that mitigates the effects of a loss of thrust anomaly, is provided by [5] for a Quad-Rotor. A second-order SMC approach is proposed in [6] to exponentially solve the position and attitude tracking problem for a Quad-Rotor. In [7] a real-time robust altitude control scheme is provided for an efficient performance of a Quad-Rotor using a chattering-free SMC approach. In [8] a nonlinear control method, based on integral backstepping and saturationbased SMC, is presented to stabilize the Quad-Rotor attitude and to reach a trajectory tracking task. In [9] a combination between a Proportional-Derivative controller and a Laplacebased compensator is proposed for robust attitude control of Quad-Rotors under some uncertainties. In [10] a block control technique, combined with the STA and robustified with a wind identification algorithm, is provided to solve the tracking trajectory problem for a Quad-Rotor affected by wind. In [11] an integral predictive robust control together with a nonlinear H ∞ controller are proposed to track a desired trajectory in a Quad-Rotor. In [12] a discontinuous modelfree-based terminal SMC is presented to control the attitude and position of a Quad-Rotor in a finite time and despite some uncertainties. Nevertheless, it presents the disadvantage of being discontinuous, as most of the SMCs previously proposed to solve the tracking control problem in a Quad-Rotor system. In [13], an observer-based control scheme is presented based on disturbance force and torque estimation. It is shown that the proposed control strategy guarantees asymptotic stability of the tracking error. In the same vein, a robust cascade controller is presented by [14] based on a robust compensation-based hierarchical control scheme for Quad-Rotors with multiple uncertainties and multiple delays. Such a scheme provides a bounded tracking error. On the other hand, in [15] a robust control strategy, based on a continuous SMC algorithm and a hierarchical approach, is provided to robustly track a desired trajectory exponentially for a Quad-Rotor despite some class of disturbances acting on the system. An asymptotic tracking controller for a Quad-Rotor is proposed by [16] using an immersion and invariance-based adaptive control together with a robust integral of the sign of the error-based controller. It is evident that the robust tracking control problem for Quad-Rotors still remains as an important and challenging problem due to the difficulty of robust control design and robust stability analysis. Moreover, it is very important to highlight that most of the works provide a bounded tracking error for disturbances acting on all the Quad-Rotor dynamics; or an asymptotic convergence to zero of the tracking error for disturbances acting on some of the Quad-Rotor dynamics.

Motivated by the aforementioned difficulties, in this paper a continuous robust tracking output-control strategy is proposed for a Quad-Rotor under the influence of external disturbances and uncertainties acting on all the Quad-Rotor dynamics. The proposed strategy is composed of a FT-SMO, that estimates and identifies the full state, from the measurable position and attitude, and some type of disturbances, respectively; and also of a combination between PID controllers and three different Continuous-SMCs, that robustly track a desired timevarying trajectory with exponential convergence and despite the influence of external disturbances and uncertainties acting on all the Quad-Rotor dynamics 1 . The closed-loop stability is provided based on ISS [17] and FT-ISS [18] properties that ensure the exponential convergence to zero of the tracking error dynamics. It is well-known that to guarantee the closedloop stability for an underactuated system, as the Quad-Rotor, is not straightforward. Some experimental results validate the provided control strategy. It is worth mentioning that the strategy is completely continuous and it has not been tested before in a Quad-Rotor system.

The outline of this work is as follows. The problem statement is introduced in Section II. Some preliminary definitions are given in Section III. The robust tracking control strategy and the main result are described in Section IV. The corresponding experimental resua combination between PID controllers and Continuous Sliding-Modes Controllers (Continuous-SMCs)lts are depicted in Section V. Some concluding remarks are discussed in Section VI. Finally, some preliminary results and the proofs for the main results are given in the Appendix.
div.formula: Notation: Denote R + = {x ∈ R : x ≥ 0},

div.head: II. PROBLEM STATEMENT
div.p: Consider the Quad-Rotor dynamics, which describes the dynamical behavior of the QBall2 by Quanser (see, Fig. 1, and for more modeling details see [2], [19], [12]), i.e.
div.formula: ẍ = ax ẋ + um(sφsψ + cφcψsθ) + dx(t), (1a) ÿ = ay ẏ + um(cφsθsψ -cψsφ) + dy(t), (1b) z = az ż + umcφcθ -g + dz(t), (1c) θ = τ θ + b θ φ ψ + d θ (t), (1d) φ = τ φ + b φ ψ θ + d φ (t), (1e) ψ = τ ψ + b ψ φ θ + d ψ (t),(1f)
div.p: where x, y ∈ R are the coordinates in the horizontal plane, z ∈ R is the vertical position, θ, φ, ψ ∈ R are the pitch angle (around the y-axis), the roll angle (around the x-axis) and the yaw angle (around the z-axis), respectively. The term u m := u/m with u ∈ R representing the main thrust and m ∈ R + denotes the mass of the Quad-Rotor; while the pitching, rolling and yawing moments are given by τ θ , τ φ , τ ψ ∈ R, respectively. The relationship between the control inputs u, τ θ , τ φ , τ ψ and the thrust of each rotor, i.e.
div.formula: f i , i = 1, 4, is given by u = 4 i=1 f i , τ θ = l(f 2 -f 4 ), τ φ = l(f 3 -f 1 ) and τ ψ = C(-f 1 + f 2 -f 3 + f 4 )
div.p: , with C being a positive constant that depends on the rotor properties and l the distance from the center of mass to the rotor (for more details, see [20]).

The inertial coefficients a x := (I x -I y )/I z , a y := (I z -I x )/I y , a z := (I y -I z )/I x , with I x , I y and I z being the moments of inertia along x, y, and z-axis, respectively; and b ψ , b θ and b φ represent the aerodynamic damping coefficients. Such moments of inertia and aerodynamic damping coefficients are considered unknown, and hence, these terms represent some uncertainties in the model.
The
div.formula: = a z ż + d z (t) ∈ L Dz , dθ (t) := b θ φ(t) ψ(t) + d θ (t) ∈ L D θ , dφ (t) := b φ ψ(t) θ(t) + d φ (t) ∈ L D φ , dψ (t) := b ψ φ(t) θ(t) + d ψ (t) ∈ L D ψ and ḋx (t) ∈ L Dx , ḋy (t) ∈ L Dy , ḋz (t) ∈ L Dz , ḋθ (t) ∈ L Dθ , ḋφ (t) ∈ L Dφ , ḋψ (t) ∈ L Dψ ; with known positive constants D x , D y , D z , D θ , D ψ , D ψ ,
div.p: Dx , Dy , Dz , Dθ , Dφ and Dψ . Moreover, it is considered that just the positions x, y and z; and the angles θ, φ and ψ are available for measuring.

The aim of this paper is to provide different Continuous-SMC strategies to robustly track a desired trajectory for the coordinates x, y, z and the angle ψ of the Quad-Rotor, despite some bounded uncertainties and disturbances, by means of only the measurable positions and angles, and verify some of the proposed control strategies experimentally.

div.head: III. PRELIMINARIES
div.p: A continuous function α : R + → R + belongs to class K if it is strictly increasing and α(0) = 0; it belongs to class K ∞ if it is also unbounded. A continuous function β : R + ×R + → R + belongs to class KL if for each fixed s, β(•, s) ∈ K, and β(r, •) is strictly decreasing to zero for any fixed r ∈ R + . The function β belongs to class KL T if for each fixed s, β(•, s) ∈ K, and for each fixed r, there exists 0 < T (r) < ∞ such that β(r, s) is decreasing to zero with respect to s < T (r), and β(r, s) = 0 for all s ≥ T (r).
Consider a time-dependent differential equation [21]:
div.formula: dx(t) dt = f (t, x(t)), t ≥ t 0 , t 0 ∈ R,(2)
div.p: where x(t) ∈ R n is the state vector; f : R × R n → R n is a continuous function with respect to x and piece-wise continuous with respect to t, f (t, 0) = 0 for all t ∈ R. The solution of the system (2), for an initial condition x 0 ∈ R n at time instant t 0 ∈ R, is denoted as x(t, t 0 , x 0 ) and defined on some finite time interval [t 0 , t 0 + T ) such that 0 ≤ T < ∞.
Let Ω be open neighborhood of the origin in R n , 0 ∈ Ω.

div.head: Definition 1.
div.p: [21], [22]. At the steady state x = 0, the system (2) is said to be a) Uniformly Stable (US) if for any > 0 there is δ( ) such that for any
div.formula: x 0 ∈ Ω, if ||x 0 || ≤ δ( ) then ||x(t, t 0 , x 0 )|| ≤ for all t ≥ t 0 , for any t 0 ∈ R; b) Uniformly Exponentially Stable (UES)
div.p: if it is US and exponentially converging from Ω, i.e. for any x 0 ∈ Ω there exist k, γ > 0 such that ||x(t, t 0 , x 0 )|| ≤ k||x 0 ||e -γ(t-t0) for all t ≥ t 0 , for any t 0 ∈ R; c) Uniformly Finite-Time Stable (UFTS) if it is US and finite-time converging from Ω, i.e. for any x 0 ∈ Ω there exists
div.formula: 0 ≤ T x0 < +∞ such that x(t, t 0 , x 0 ) = 0 for all t ≥ t 0 + T x0 , for any t 0 ∈ R. The function T 0 (x 0 ) = inf{T x0 ≥ 0 : x(t, t 0 , x 0 ) = 0 ∀t ≥ t 0 + T x0 } is called the settling-time of the system (2).
div.p: If Ω = R n , then x = 0 is said to be globally US (GUS), UES (GUES), or UFTS (GUFTS), respectively.

div.head: IV. ROBUST TRACKING CONTROL
div.p: In the following, the design of the proposed control strategies to track the Quad-Rotor positions is addressed. The proposed robust tracking is composed by sliding-modes observers (SMOs) and cascaded Continuous-SMCs. Firstly, the design of the sliding-modes observers is presented.

div.head: A. Finite-Time Sliding-Mode Observer
div.p: Consider the following state space representation of (1), i.e.
div.formula: ξ1 = ξ 2 , ξ2 = g ξ (η 1 )u m -G + d ξ (t), (3a) η1 = η 2 , η2 = τ + d η (t),(3b)
div.p: where
div.formula: ξ 1 := (x, y, z) T ∈ R 3 , ξ 2 := ( ẋ, ẏ, ż) T ∈ R 3 , η 1 := (θ, φ, ψ) T ∈ R 3 , η 2 := ( θ, φ, ψ) T ∈ R 3 , d ξ := ( dx , dy , dz ) T ∈ R 3 and d η := ( dθ , dφ , dψ ) T ∈ R 3 rep-
div.p: resent positions, linear velocities, angles, angular velocities and the corresponding disturbances, respectively; the terms G := (0, 0, g) T ∈ R 3 and τ := (τ θ , τ φ , τ ψ ) T ∈ R 3 are the vectors of gravity and the angular moment, respectively; while the function g ξ : R 3 → R 3 is given as g ξ (η 1 ) := (sφsψ + sθcφcψ, sθcφsψ -sφcψ, cθcφ) T . Let us consider the following Finite-Time SMO (FT-SMO)
where êξ := ξ 1 -ξ1 ∈ R 3 and êη := η 1 -η1 ∈ R 3 are the output errors, respectively; the nonlinear output injections ϕ 1 , ϕ 2 , ϕ 3 : R 3 → R 3 are given as
with the function s γ := ( s 1 γ , ..., s n γ ) T , for any s = (s 1 , ..., s n ) ∈ R n ; and some design diagonal matrix gains Ki = diag( ki1 , ki2 , ki3 ) ∈ R 3 × R 3 with i = 1, 6.

Define the state estimation error as ê := (ê ξ , εξ , êη , εη ) T ∈ R 12 , where εξ := ξ 2 -ξ2 ∈ R 3 , εη := η 2 -η2 ∈ R 3 are the linear and angular velocity errors, respectively. The following theorem describes the finite-time convergence properties of the FT-SMO. Theorem 1. [15]. Let the observer (4) be applied to system (3). Suppose that the observer parameters are selected as:
ψ , k63 = 1.1 Dψ ; then, at the steady state ê = 0, the state estimation error dynamics is UFTS.

div.head: B. Horizontal Disturbance Identification
div.p: Define ˆ ξ := d ξ (t) -ξ3 and ˆ η := d η (t) -η3 . Hence, the corresponding error dynamics can be written as follows
div.formula: ėξ = εξ -K1ϕ1(êξ), ėη = εη -K4ϕ1(êη), εξ = ˆ ξ -K2ϕ2(êξ), εη = ˆ η -K5ϕ2(êη), ˙ ξ = ḋξ (t) -K3ϕ3(êξ), ˙ η = ḋη(t) -K6ϕ3(êη).
div.p: According to Theorem 1, such an error dynamics is UFTS,
div.formula: which implies that ξ1 (t) = ξ 1 (t), ξ2 (t) = ξ 2 (t), ξ3 (t) = d ξ (t) and η1 (t) = η 1 (t), η2 (t) = η 2 (t), η3 (t) = d η (t), for all t ≥ T o > 0.
div.p: Hence, if the corresponding disturbance terms d ξ (t) and d η (t) are uniformly bounded and Lipschitz continuous, as it was assumed, then the FT-SMO given by (4) provides the following disturbance identifications for all t ≥ T o ξ3(t) = ( ξx(t), ξy(t), ξz(t))
T = ( dx(t), dy(t), dz(t)) T , (5a)
div.formula: η3(t) = (η θ (t), ηφ (t), ηψ (t)) T = ( dθ (t), dφ (t), dψ (t)) T . (5b)
div.p: Note that such identification terms will be used to robustify any type of continuous control strategy, including a simple linear strategy.

div.head: C. Control Design
div.p: In this section, a combination between PID controllers (for the virtual controllers) and three different Continuous-SMCs (for the main thrust and moments) is proposed. Define the desired trajectories as x d , y d , z d , ψ d ∈ C ∞ and bounded. Then, the tracking error vectors can be given as
div.formula: e ξ = (ex, ey, ez) T := ξ1 -ξ d , eη = (e θ , e φ , e ψ ) T := η1 -η d , ε ξ = (εx, εy, εz) T := ξ2 -ξd , εη = (ε θ , ε φ , ε ψ ) T := η2 -ηd , where ξ d := (x d , y d , z d ) T ∈ R 3 and η d := (θ , φ , ψ d ) T ∈ R 3
div.p: are the desired position and attitude vectors, respectively; with θ and φ being some reference signals to be designed. Then, the tracking error dynamics is given as
div.formula: ėξ = ε ξ , εξ = g ξ (η 1 )u m -G + d ξ (t) -ξd , (6a) ėη = ε η , εη = τ + d η (t) -ηd ,(6b)
div.p: with initial conditions e ξ0 := e ξ (0) ∈ R 3 , ε ξ0 := ε ξ (0) ∈ R 3 , e η0 := e η (0) ∈ R 3 and ε η0 := ε η (0) ∈ R 3 . Note that, due to the under-actuated nature of the Quad-Rotor, one cannot control all the positions and angles independently. Hence, the references signals θ and φ as well as the control input u m and τ must be properly designed in order to achieve a desired position ξ d and a desired angle ψ d . To do this, a virtual control ν := (ν x , ν y , ν z ) T ∈ R 3 is introduced in the position error dynamics, i.e.
div.formula: ėξ = ε ξ , εξ = ν + w ξ (η 1 , u m , ν) + d ξ -ξd , (7a) ėη = ε η , εη = τ + d η (t) -ηd ,(7b)
div.p: where the disturbance term w ξ ∈ R 3 is given as w ξ (η1, um, ν) = (wx, wy, wz) := g ξ (η1)um -G -ν. Thus, the virtual control ν may be chosen as follows [16] νx = um(sφ sψ d + sθ cφ cψ d ), (8a)
div.formula: νy = um(sθ cφ sψ d -sφ cψ d ), (8b) νz = umcθ cφ -g,(8c)
div.p: and then, calculate the main thrust u m and the references signals θ and φ from (8), i.e.
div.formula: um = ν 2 x + ν 2 y + (νz + g) 2 ,(9a)
θ = arcsin[u -1 m (νxsψ d -νycψ d )],(9b)
φ = arctan[(νz + g) -1 (νxcψ d + νysψ d )].(9c)
div.p: Therefore, the objective now is to design the virtual controller ν and the control input τ such that the tracking error vector e := (e ξ , ε ξ , e η , ε η ) T ∈ R 12 converges to zero despite some bounded uncertainties and disturbances. In order to fulfill such an objective, it will be shown that system (7a) is ISS with respect to e η , and then, it will be demonstrated that system (7b) is GUFTS.

div.head: C.1. Position Control Design
div.p: Let us propose the following PID virtual controllers for ν x and ν y νx = kx 0 ēx + kx 1 ex + kx 2 εx + ẍd -ξx, (10a) νy = ky 0 ēy + ky 1 ey + ky 2 εy + ÿd -ξy, (10b)
div.formula: νz = νz + zd -ξz,(10c)
div.p: where ēx := t 0 e x (τ )dτ , ēy := t 0 e y (τ )dτ ; the gains k xj , k yj , with j = 0, 2, are such that the following matrices
are Hurwitz, and νz can be designed between one of the three following Continuous-SMCs: a) Continuous Singular Terminal Sliding-Mode Control (Continuous-STSMC) [23]:
div.formula: s z = ε z + k z1 e z 2 3 , νz = v -k z2 s z 1 2 , (12a
div.p: One possible selection to design the gains k zi , with i = 1, 3, is given in Table I. 1.1ζ > 0 b) Continuous Nonsingular Terminal Sliding-Mode control (Continuous-NTSMC) [24]:
div.formula: s z = ε z + k z1 e z 3 2 , νz = v -k z2 s z 1 3 , (13a) v = -k z3 s z 0 .(13b)
div.p: A possible selection for the gains k zi , with i = 1, 3, is given by [24] and shown in Table II.

div.head: 2.5ζ
div.p: c) Continuous Twisting control (Continuous-TC) [25]:
div.formula: νz = v -k z1 e z 1 3 -k z2 ε z 1 2 , (14a
) v = -k z3 e z 0 -k z4 ε z 0 .(14b)
div.p: A possible choice for the gains k z l , with l = 1, 4, is given by [25] and depicted in Table III. Then, the following result can be established.

Theorem 2. Let the control (10) be applied to system (1). Suppose that k xj , k yj , with j = 0, 2, are such that matrices (11) are Hurwitz, and νz is designed according to any of the Continuous-SMCs, i.e. ( 12), ( 13) or (14). Then, system (7a) is ISS with respect to e η . Particularly, the tracking errors for x and y are ISS while the tracking error for z is FT-ISS.
All the corresponding proofs are given in the Appendix.

div.head: C.2. Attitude Control Design
div.p: It is clear that the attitude tracking error dynamics (7b) can be viewed as a block diagonal decoupled dynamics with three independent control inputs. Hence, due to such a decoupling between position and attitude dynamics, the position control is designed as a high-level control while the attitude control as a low-level control.
Let us propose the following attitude control
div.formula: τ θ = τθ -ηθ , τ φ = τφ -ηφ , τ ψ = τψ + ψd -ηψ ,(15)
div.p: where τθ , τφ and τψ can also be designed by choosing one of the three different Continuous-SMCs, described in the previous section, using their corresponding tracking errors, i.e. e θ , ε θ , e φ , ε φ , e ψ and ε ψ , respectively. Hence, the following result can be provided.

Theorem 3. Let the control (15) be applied to system (1). Suppose that τθ , τφ and τψ are designed according to any of the Continuous-SMCs, i.e. (12), ( 13) or (14). Then, at steady state (e η , ε η ) = 0, the system (7b) is GUFTS.
Therefore, according to Theorem 2, it is given that
div.formula: e ξ (t, e ξ0 , ε ξ , eη) ε ξ (t, e ξ , ε ξ0 , eη) ≤ β ξ e ξ0 ε ξ0 , t + γ ξ (||eη||∞),(16)
div.p: for all t ≥ 0, some β ξ ∈ KL and γ ξ ∈ K. Now, let us recall that the disturbance term w ξ can be written as
div.formula: w ξ (η1, um, ν) = um     sφsψ + sθcφcψ sθcφsψ -sφcψ cθcφ   -   sφ sψ d + sθ cφ cψ d sθ cφ sψ d -sφ cψ d cθ cφ     ,
div.p: and due to the fact that such a function is Lipschitz in η 1 on R 3 and continuous in u m on R, it follows that
for some positive L ξ > 0. Then, according to Theorem 3, it follows that e η (t) = 0, for all t ≥ T η > 0. This implies that the disturbance term w ξ vanishes when e η = 0; and hence, ( 16) satisfies
div.formula: e ξ (t, e ξ0 , ε ξ , e η ) ε ξ (t, e ξ , ε ξ0 , e η ) ≤ β ξ e ξ0 ε ξ0 , t ,(17)
div.p: for all t ≥ T η , which implies that, at (e ξ , ε ξ ) = 0, the system (7a) is GUES. In this way, the main result has been proven and it is summarized in the following Theorem.

Theorem 4. Let the control (9), ( 10) and (15) be applied to system (1). Suppose that k xj , k yj , with j = 0, 2, are such that matrices (11) are Hurwitz; νz , τθ , τφ and τψ are designed according to any of the Continuous-SMCs, i.e. ( 12), ( 13) or (14). Then, at steady state (e ξ , ε ξ , e η , ε η ) = 0, the system (6) is GUES.

div.head: V. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
div.p: The proposed control strategy is applied to the QBall2 by Quanser depicted by Fig. 1. This research experimental platform uses a ground control station with the real-time control software QUARC , that allows to create a direct interface with MATLAB /Simulink . The QBall2 position and attitude are tracked and accurately measured using a OptiTrack TM camera system with six synchronized infrared cameras connected to the ground station.

The FT-SMO ( 4) and the continuous robust control ( 9), ( 10) and ( 15), with νz , τθ , τφ , τψ designed as Continuous-STSMCs, are implemented in MATLAB /Simulink . The parameters for the FT-SMO and the continuous robust control are given in Table IV. Recall that the control strategy uses the estimated velocities provided by the FT-SMO. In this case the Quad-Rotor is dealing with a regulation task where the desired trajectories x d and y d are just piece-wise continuous in order to better illustrate the workability of the proposed control strategy. The results are depicted by Figs. 23. The corresponding desired trajectory and the real position and attitude tracked by the QBall2 are shown in Fig. 2. It is clear that the QBall2 tracks the desired trajectory with a good precision despite the intrinsic disturbances of the system and taking into account that a very simple model was considered for the control design. On the other hand, the control signals are depicted in Fig. 3.
The second desired trajectory (tracking task) was designed as ψ d (t) = 0 and

For this case the Quad-Rotor is dealing with a tracking task where the desired trajectories x d , y d and z d are also piecewise continuous. The results are shown by Figs. 45. The proposed desired trajectory and the real position and attitude tracked by the QBall2 are depicted by Fig. 4. Once again, the QBall2 tracks the desired trajectory with a good precision in spite of model uncertainties of the system. On the other hand, the control signals are depicted in Fig. 5. Due to space limitation, comparisons with other robust control strategies are out of the scope of this paper. The proper and fair comparisons (e.g. analysis of the convergence time, steady state error, RMS values, maximum tracking error, etc.) are postponed to other publication highlighting that this work is only focused on the presentation of this new Continuous-SMC strategy.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSIONS
div.p: This paper deals with the robust tracking output-control problem for a Quad-Rotor under the influence of external disturbances and uncertainties. The proposed robust strategy is composed of a FT-SMO, that estimates and identifies the full state, from the measurable position and attitude, and some type of disturbances, respectively; and also of a combination between PID controllers and three different Continuous-SMCs, that robustly track a desired time-varying trajectory with exponential convergence and despite the influence of external disturbances and uncertainties. The closed-loop stability is provided based on ISS and FT-ISS properties that ensure the exponential convergence to zero of the tracking error dynamics. Theoretically speaking, the proposed control strategy, using any of the proposed Continuous-SMCs (STSMC, NTSMC or TC), provides the same result, i.e. Global Uniform Exponential Stability of the tracking error. The experimental results validate the performance of the proposed control strategy using the Continuous-STSMCs. It is clear that, due to the lack of space, a formal and proper comparison experimental study of the different Continuous-SMCs is postponed. However, these issues are in the scope for future work as well as the control design considering communication delays that clearly appear in the QBall2 real-time application.

div.head: APPENDIX
div.p: For any r i > 0, with i = 1, n, and λ > 0, define the dilation matrix Λ r (λ) = diag{λ ri } n i=1 , the vector of weights r = (r 1 , . . . , r n ) T , and the homogeneous norm, defined for any x ∈ R n , as ||x||r = ( n i=1 ||xi|| ρ r i ) 1 ρ , ρ = n i=1 ri. For all x ∈ R n , its Euclidean norm ||x|| is related with the homogeneous one [26] as α r (||x|| r ) ≤ ||x|| ≤ α r (||x|| r ), for some α r , α r ∈ K ∞ . Due to this "equivalence", stability analysis with respect to the norm ||x|| may be substituted with analysis for the norm ||x|| r . The homogeneous norm has an important property that is ||Λ r (λ)x|| r = λ||x|| r for all x ∈ R n . Define S r = {x ∈ R n : ||x|| r = 1}. Definition 2. [27]. The function g : R n → R is called rhomogeneous (r i > 0, with i = 1, n), if for any x ∈ R n the relation g(Λ r (λ)x) = λ q g(x), holds for some q ∈ R and all λ > 0. The function f : R n → R n is called rhomogeneous (r i > 0, with i = 1, n), if for any x ∈ R n the relation f (Λ r (λ)x) = λ q Λ r (λ)f (x), holds for some q ≥ -min 1≤i≤n r i and all λ > 0. In both cases, the constant q is called the degree of homogeneity.
Homogeneous systems possess certain robustness with respect to external disturbances. Consider a system described by the following differential inclusion

where x and d have the same meaning as in (2), and : R n+m ⇒ R n is a set-valued map. Similarly to system (2), for an initial condition x 0 ∈ R n and input d ∈ L ∞ , define the corresponding solution by ϕ(t, x 0 , d), for any t ≥ 0 and denote by S(x 0 ) as the set of solutions ϕ(t, x 0 , d) corresponding to the common initial condition x 0 . Definition 3. [18]. System (18) is said to be finite-time inputto-state stable (FT-ISS) if for all x 0 ∈ R n and d ∈ L D the estimate: ||ϕ(t, x 0 , d)|| ≤ β(||x 0 ||, t)+γ(||d|| ∞ ), holds for all t ≥ 0 and ϕ(t, x 0 , d) ∈ S(x 0 ) for some β ∈ KL T and γ ∈ K.

For a system represented by the differential equation ( 2), the classic definition of ISS can be obtained if it is assumed that β ∈ KL (see, for instance [17]). Let us denote an extended discontinuous function F (x, d) = (F T (x, d), 0 m ) T . Theorem 5. [18]. Let F be homogeneous with weights r = (r 1 , . . . , r n ) > 0 and r = (r 1 , . . . , rm ) ≥ 0 with a degree q ≥ -min 1≤i≤n r i , i.e. F (Λ r x, Λ r d) = λ q Λ r F (x, d). Assume that the system (18) is globally asymptotically stable for d = 0. Let
div.formula: ||F (z, d) -F (z, 0)|| ≤ σ(||d||), σ(s) = cs ρ min , if s ≤ 1, cs ρmax , if s > 1,
div.p: for all z ∈ S r , some c > 0 and ρ max ≥ ρ min > 0. Then, the system (18) is ISS if rmin > 0, where rmin = min 1≤j≤m rj . If the homogeneity degree q < 0, then the system (18) is FT-ISS.
After these preliminary results, everything is ready to provide the proofs of Theorem 2 and 3, respectively.

Proof of Theorem 2. Firstly, let us prove that the tracking error dynamics for z is FT-ISS with respect to e η when the 0278-0046 (c) 2018 IEEE. Continuous-STSMC (12) is applied. Then, the tracking error dynamics for z is given as follows
div.formula: ėz = εz, εz = v -kz 2 sz 1 2 + wz,(19a)
v = -kz 3 sz 0 ,(19b)
div.p: where
div.formula: s z = ε z + k z1 e z 2 3
div.p: . Define the following set-valued map
div.formula: F ( z , v, w z ) = F ( z , v, wz) 0 =   εz v -kz 2 sz 1 2 + wz -kz 3 sz 0 0   ,
div.p: with z := (e z , ε z ) T ∈ R 2 . This discontinuous function is homogeneous of degree q z = -1 with weights r z = (3, 2, 1) and rwz = 1. In [23], it has been proven that, for w z = 0, the quadratic form
div.formula: V z = ζ T P z ζ, with ζ T = ( e z 2 3
div.p: s z v 2 ) and some 0 < P T z = P z ∈ R 3×3 , is a Lyapunov function for system (19) such that, for some zi , i = 1, 3, Vz ≤ -κ z V 3/4 z , with some positive κ z . Therefore, at
div.formula: ( z , v) = 0, system (19) is GUFTS. Moreover, it is given that ||F ( z , v, wz) -F ( z , v, 0)|| = ||wz|| ≤ Lz||eη||, Lz||eη|| ≤ σ(||eη||), ∀ez, εz, v ∈ R,
div.p: with σ(s) = cs ρmin , if s ≤ 1; or σ(s) = cs ρmax , if s > 1, for c ≥ L z and ρ max = ρ min = 1. Hence, all the conditions of Theorem 1 hold, and due to min rwz = 1 > 0, system ( 19) is FT-ISS3 with respect to e η , i.e.
for all t ≥ 0 and some β z ∈ KL T and γ z ∈ K.
Let us prove now that the tracking error for x coordinate is ISS with respect to e η . Therefore, if ν x is designed as in (8a), the tracking error dynamics for x is given as follows
div.formula: ˙ x = (A + BKx) x + Bwx,(21)
div.p: where x := (ē x , e x , ε x ) T ∈ R 3 and K

. Due to the fact that the pair (A, B) is controllable, there always exists a matrix K x such that A + BK x is Hurwitz. Therefore, one may use any classic linear control technique, e.g. pole-placement, LQR, LMI approaches, etc., to design the matrix K x and show that, for w x = 0, at the steady state = 0, system (21) is UES. Then, since ||w x || ∞ ≤ L x ||e η || ∞ , for all x ∈ R and some L x > 0, one can easily show that system (21) is ISS with respect to e η . In order to conclude the proof, one can follows the same previous steps to demonstrate that the tracking error for y coordinate is also ISS with respect to e η . Proof of Theorem 3. Let us prove that the tracking error dynamics for θ is GUFTS when the Continuous-TC (14) is applied. Thus, the closed-loop dynamics for θ is given as
div.formula: ėθ = ε θ , εθ = v -k θ 1 e θ 1 3 -k θ 2 ε θ 1 2 , (22a) v = -k θ 3 e θ 0 -k θ 4 ε θ 0 - ... θ ,(22b)
div.p: where v := v -θ . Is is easy to show that system (22) is homogeneous of degree q θ = -1 with weights r θ = (3, 2, 1).
In [25], it has been shown that there exist coefficients β j , with j = 1, 4, such that the function V θ (e θ , ε θ , v) = β1|e θ |
div.formula: 5 3 + β2e θ ε θ + β3|ε θ | 5 2 + β4e θ v 2 -β5ε θ v3 + β6|v| 5
div.p: , is a Lyapunov function for system (22), and that for k θj , with j = 1, 4, being selected as in Table III , with some positive κ θ . This implies that, at (e θ , ε θ , v) = 0, system is (22) GUFTS.
Then, let us show that the tracking error dynamics for φ is GUFTS when the Continuous-NTSMC (13) is used. The closed-loop dynamics for φ is given as
div.formula: ėφ = ε φ , εφ = v -k φ 2 s φ 1 3 , (23a) v = -k φ 3 s φ 0 - ... φ ,(23b)
div.p: where s φ = ε φ + k φ1 e φ 3 2 and v := v -φ . One can show that system (23) is also homogeneous of degree φ = -1 with weights r φ = (3, 2, 1). In [24], it is shown that there exist coefficients β j , with j = 1, 2, such that the function
div.formula: V φ (e φ , ε φ , v) = β1|e φ | 5 3 + e φ ε φ + 2 5 k φ 1 |ε φ | 5 2 -1 k 3 φ 1 ε φ v3 + β2|v| 5 ,
div.p: is a Lyapunov function for system (23) and that for k φj , with j = 1, 3, being selected as in Table II assuming that || ... φ || ∞ ≤ ζ, its derivative satisfies Vφ ≤ -κ φ V 4/5 φ , with some positive κ φ . Thus, this implies that, at (e φ , ε φ , v) = 0, system (23) is also GUFTS 4 .

It is clear that the closed-loop dynamics for ψ presents the same structure as (19). Then, one could apply any of the three Continuous-SMCs, i.e. (12), (13) or (14), and show that the tracking error dynamics for ψ is also GUFTS. This concludes the proof.

Denote sx := sin x and cx := cos x and define the function a γ := |a| γ sign(a) for any a ∈ R and γ ∈ R ≥0 .

figure.figDesc: assuming that || ... θ || ∞ ≤ ζ, such a Lyapunov function satisfies Vθ ≤ -κ θ V

note.p: In our previous work[15], a similar control strategy has been presented. However, only one Continuous-SMC was proposed, the stability analysis was not carried out using ISS properties and just simulation results were provided.

In the classic SMC approach, such uncertainties and disturbances are only assumed uniformly bounded but the control law is discontinuous. In order to have a continuous and robust control law, a smaller class of uncertainties and disturbances is considered. However, it is worth saying that positions, angles, velocities and accelerations as well as the control inputs are physically bounded in practice; and the possible external disturbances, as wind gusts, are modeled most of the times as sinusoidal signals which are clearly bounded and Lipschitz continuous.

It is possible to show that the tracking error dynamics for when the Continuous-NTSMC and Continuous-TC are applied, is also homogeneous of degree qz = -1 with weights rz = (3, 2, 1). Thus, one can prove, for each case, that system (19) is FT-ISS following the same given steps.

In general, the boundedness conditions over θ and φ could be restrictive. However, if the Quad-Rotor is not going to deal with aggressive maneuvers, such boundedness conditions can always be satisfied. This consideration is taken into account in this paper.
